across.text: Font by Norma, perhaps
across.explanation: TIMES NEW ROMAN(i.e. “font”). Solution is TIMES (i.e. “[multiplied] by”) followed by NEW ROMAN (i.e. “Norma, perhaps” – “new” is sometimes used by setters to indicate an anagram, so NEW ROMAN cryptically indicates Roman is an anagram of “Norma”. You get the idea.)

across.text: Dine without fish and put up with endless sweet
across.explanation: SUGARPLUM(i.e. “sweet”). Solution is SUP (i.e. “dine”, specifically an archaic word meaning to take one’s evening meal, or supper) placed outside or “without” GAR (i.e. “fish”, specifically a garfish) and then followed by LUMP (i.e. “put up with”, as in “to like it or lump it”) with its final letter removed (indicated by “endless”), like so: SU(GAR)P-LUM.

across.text: Green politician in Montreal opposition
across.explanation: REALO(i.e. “Green politician”, specifically one in the less radical side of the German Green Party, it says here). “In” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: MONT(REAL O)PPOSITION. One I got from the wordplay, if I’m honest.

across.text: Bring round one affected by ecstasy right in disco?
across.explanation: DISENTRANCE(i.e. “bring round”). Solution is I (Roman numeral “one”) then SENT [into…] (i.e. “affected by ecstasy”) then R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”) all wrapped up “in” DANCE (i.e. “disco”), like so: D(I-SENT-R)ANCE.

across.text: Genius way of doing things in study
across.explanation: DEMON(i.e. “genius”, as in being very good, or a demon, in some endeavour). Solution is MO (i.e. “way of doing thing”, specifically Modus Operandi) placed “in” DEN (i.e. “study [room]”), like so: DE(MO)N.

across.text: Involving VIPs drunk, even
across.explanation: HIGH-LEVEL(i.e. “involving VIPs” – if something is high-level then it’s intended for the movers and shakers of an organisation). Solution is HIGH (i.e. “drunk”) followed by LEVEL (i.e. “even”).

across.text: Stravinsky, perhaps very removed from American vitality
across.explanation: IGOR(i.e. “Stravinsky, perhaps” – as in the fella’s first name). Solution is VIGOR (i.e. “American vitality”, i.e. how the US spells “vigour”) with the V (a recognised abbreviation of “very”) “removed” from the beginning.

across.text: Extremely fresh where the IOW ferry operates
across.explanation: INSOLENT. Solution satisfies “extremely fresh”, as in giving someone some lip, and “where the IOW ferry operates” – IOW being Isle of Wight, and its ferry would therefore operate IN [the] SOLENT. I rather liked this clue.

across.text: People regularly touchy about reward for winners
across.explanation: OCCUPY(i.e. “[to] people”). Solution is OCY (i.e. “regularly touchy”, i.e. every other letter of the wordTOUCHY) placed “about” CUP (i.e. “reward for winners”), like so: OC(CUP)Y.

across.text: A thing that’s PC upset perceptual morons
across.explanation: PERSONAL COMPUTER(i.e. “a thing that’s PC”). “Upset” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PERCEPTUAL MORONS.

across.text: Soldier retreats in confusion after start of D-Day
across.explanation: DESERT RAT(i.e. “soldier”, specifically a solider in the 7th Armoured Division of the British Army active during World War II). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “in confusion”) of RETREATS placed “after” D (i.e. “start of D-Day”, as in its first letter), like so: D-ESERTRAT.

across.text: Evil embraced by doctors’ revolts
across.explanation: RISINGS(i.e. “revolts”). Solution is SIN (i.e. “evil”) placed in or “embraced by” RIGS (i.e. “doctors”, e.g. to rig an election is to doctor its results), like so: RI(SIN)GS.

across.text: Judicial decision to abolish court note writer
across.explanation: GiuseppeVERDI(19th century composer, or “note writer”). Solution is VERDICT (i.e. “judicial decision”) with the CT removed (indicated by “to abolish court” – CT being a recognised abbreviation of “court”).

across.text: Botticelli, perhaps, using same egg mixture
across.explanation: GUESSING GAME(i.e. “Botticelli, perhaps” – Botticelli is a game where players have to guess the identity of a person through yes/no questions after an initial letter has been given. Not one I’ve played, though I am a fan of yes/no riddles). “Mixture” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of USING SAME EGG.

across.text: Small shrub in grass, a lentil transformed
across.explanation: POTENTILLA(i.e. “small shrub” – one I have no shame in looking up as there are thousands of the buggers to choose from). Solution is POT (i.e. “grass”, both nicknames for marijuana) followed by an anagram (indicated by “transformed”) of A LENTIL, like so: POT-ENTILLA.

across.text: A shift that drops four with a routine job
across.explanation: NINE-TO-FIVE(i.e. “a routine job”). Solution riffs on how “shifting” four from nine gives you five, taking you from “nine [down] to five”. You get the idea. Again.

across.text: What’s used in adding carriage and track for former guard
across.explanation: CARRY-FORWARD(i.e. “what’s used in adding” – ask your grandparents, kids). Solution is CAR (i.e. “carriage”) followed by RY (i.e. “track”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of railway), then FOR and finally WARD (i.e. “guard” –“former” seems a redundant word, unless I’m missing something), like so: CAR-RY-FOR-WARD.

across.text: End of skewer used in turning rump steak may be wanted thus?
across.explanation: RARER(i.e. “steak may be wanted thus”). Solution is R (i.e. “end of skewer”, i.e. the last letter of “skewer”) “used in” REAR (i.e. “rump”) which is reversed (indicated by “turning”), like so: RA(R)ER.

across.text: Pain in mouth, but not quite windpipe
across.explanation: TRACHEA(i.e. “windpipe”). Solution is ACHE (i.e. “pain”) placed “in” TRAP (i.e. “mouth”) which has its final letter removed (indicated by “but not quite”), like so: TR(ACHE)A.

across.text: Papers sent out after account mishaps
across.explanation: ACCIDENTS(i.e. “mishaps”). Solution is ID (i.e. “papers”) and an anagram (indicated by “out”) of SENT, which are both placed “after” ACC (a recognised abbreviation of “account”), like so: ACC-ID-ENTS.

across.text: Begin again with fresh filling in pie, ale and a starter of fish
across.explanation: TURN OVER A NEW LEAF(i.e. “begin again”). Solution is TURNOVER (i.e. “pie”) and ALE being “filled” by NEW (i.e. “fresh”) and then followed by A and finally F (i.e. “starter of fish”, i.e. the first letter of “fish”), like so: TURNOVER-A(NEW)LE-A-F.

across.text: Cat’s way of acting with long established right
across.explanation: MOUSER(i.e. “cat”). Solution is MO (i.e. “way of acting”, i.e. our friend Modus Operandi again) followed by USER (a legal term meaning “long-established right” – not one I’m familiar with but it’s in the dictionary).

across.text: Stop old boys lorry taking away 1000 tons
across.explanation: OBSTRUCT(i.e. “stop”). Solution is OBS (a recognised abbreviation of “old boy” made plural) followed by TRUCK (i.e. “lorry”) with the K removed (indicated by “taking away 1000”), then T (a recognised abbreviation of “tons”), like so: OBS-TRUC-T.

across.text: Chap is wonderful, but no Romeo
across.explanation: BILL(i.e. “chap”). Solution is BRILL (i.e. “wonderful”) with the R removed (indicated by “but no Romeo”, being R in the phonetic alphabet).

across.text: Canadian introducing a European dress in imperial style
across.explanation: CAESARIAN(i.e. “in imperial style”). Solution is CAN (a recognised abbreviation of “Canadian”) including or “introducing” A then E (ditto “European”) then SARI (i.e. “dress”), like so: C(A-E-SARI)AN.

across.text: Breakfast food in reflux puts out small intestine, partly
across.explanation: ILEUM(i.e. “(small) intestine, partly”, specifically the lowest part of the small intestine). Solution is MUESLI (i.e. “breakfast food”) reversed (indicated by “in reflux”) and with the S removed (indicated by “puts out small” – S being a recognised abbreviation of “small”). Another really good clue that scans particularly well.

across.text: Obsolete big towns containing little space and filth
across.explanation: OBSCENITIES(i.e. “filth”). Solution is OBS (a recognised abbreviation of “obsolete”) and CITIES (i.e. “big towns”) “containing” EN (i.e. “little space” – “em” is a printing term used to describe a space the width of a letter m, so “en” is, understandably, half an em), like so: OBS-C(EN)ITIES.

across.text: Ray eating river fish
across.explanation: BREAM(i.e. “fish”). Solution is BEAM (i.e. “ray”, as in a sunbeam) “eating” R (a recognised abbreviation of “river”), like so: B(R)EAM.

across.text: Note lake with seabird in tiny American city
across.explanation: MILWAUKEE(i.e. “American city”). Solution is MI (i.e. “note” in the do-ray-mi style) followed by L (a recognised abbreviation of “lake”) and WEE (i.e. “tiny”) with AUK (i.e. “seabird”) placed inside like so: MI-L-W(AUK)EE.

across.text: Teased non-stop about old TV series
across.explanation: STEPTOE AND SON(i.e. “old TV series”). “About” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TEASED NON-STOP.

down.text: Doctor Who developing material for brand?
down.explanation: TORCHWOOD(i.e. “material for brand” – a “brand” in this case being a flaming torch). “Developing” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DOCTOR WHO. Looks like we’re seeing repeats creeping back in, as this solution onlyappeared a few weeks ago.

down.text: Maidens put up soldier cold with muscle pain
down.explanation: MYALGIC(i.e. “with muscle pain”). Solution is M (a recognised abbreviation of “maidens” used in cricket) followed by LAY (i.e. “put”) which is reversed (indicated by “up”, this being a down clue) and followed by GI (i.e. “[US] soldier”) and C (a recognised abbreviation of “cold”), like so: M-YAL-GI-C.

down.text: Soap externally lubricates openings for awkward stoppers?
down.explanation: SPOILSPORTS(i.e. “awkward stoppers”). Solution is SP (i.e. “soap externally”, i.e. the first and last letters of “soap”) followed by OILS (i.e. “lubricates”) and PORTS (i.e. “openings”).

down.text: Salad plant initially even needs a plunge into water
down.explanation: ENDIVE(i.e. “salad plant”, a member of the chicory family – another one I had to look up). Solution is EN (i.e. “initially even needs”, i.e. the first letters of “even” and “needs”) followed by DIVE (i.e. “plunge into water”).

down.text: Able to recover and take again without legal right to possession
down.explanation: RESILIENT(i.e. “able to recover”). This took some getting but the solution is RESIT (i.e. “take [exam] again”) surrounding or placed “without” LIEN (i.e. “legal right to possession”), like so: RESI(LIEN)T.

down.text: Millions against second title for respected Indian parliamentarian, an aggressive creature
down.explanation: MANTIS SHRIMP(i.e. “aggressive creature” – done a Google Images search: it looks like something that’s escaped from The Yellow Submarine. Groovy!) Solution is M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”) followed by ANTI (i.e. “against”) then S (a recognised abbreviation of “second”) then SHRI (i.e. “title for respected Indian” – also spelled “Sri”) and finally MP (i.e. “parliamentarian”). Aggressive, eh? I reckon I could take one.

down.text: Managed rising disagreement over head’s parochialism
down.explanation: NARROWNESS(i.e. “parochialism”). Solution is RAN (i.e. “managed”) reversed (indicated by “rising”, this being a down clue) then followed by ROW (i.e. “disagreement”) and NESS (i.e. “head”, as in a headland), like so: NAR-ROW-NESS.

down.text: A number dressed in blue and yellowish-brown
down.explanation: SAND(i.e. “yellowish-brown”). Solution is N (i.e. “a [variable] number”) placed or “dressed in” SAD (i.e. “blue”), like so: SA(N)D.

down.text: Fresh home produce which might one day do for all of us
down.explanation: GREENHOUSE EFFECT(i.e. “what might one day do for all of us” Cheery!). Solution is GREEN (i.e. “fresh”) followed by HOUSE (i.e. “home”) and [to] EFFECT (i.e. “produce”).

down.text: A day in port to send a message
down.explanation: RADIO(i.e. “to send a message”). Solution is A then D (a recognised abbreviation of “day”) placed “in” RIO (i.e. “port”, specifically Rio De Janeiro), like so: R(A-D)IO.

down.text: One delivering sheep on time for unit
down.explanation: LAMBERT, a “unit” of brightness. Solution is LAMBER (i.e. “one delivering sheep”) placed “on” T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”).

down.text: Beast left chamois under screen
down.explanation: MONSTER LIZARD. I’m not following this one, if I’m brutally honest. The solution could be MONSTER (i.e. “beast”) followed by L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”) and IZARD (a Pyrenean “chamois” – no, me neither), but I’ve no idea why this makes the solution “under screen”. Alternatively, the clue could be read as L-IZARD being placed “under” MONSTER (this being a down clue) to produce a “beast”, but here I fail to see how monster would be “screen”. Maybe the setter is pumped up for the new Godzilla movie, I don’t know. It’s a shitty clue either way, so I’m moving on.[EDIT: Scratch that. Solution isMONITOR LIZARD. As zouzoulap clarifies in the comments, MONITOR = “screen”. Much obliged, zouzoulap! – LP]

down.text: Ringing caught long-tailed monkey without ring
down.explanation: CLANGOUR(i.e. “ringing”). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of “caught” used in ball games) followed by LANGUR (i.e. “long tailed monkey” – done a Google Images search: Yep. Monkey.) placed around or “without” O (i.e. “ring”), like so: C-LANG(O)UR.

down.text: Turn to somebody coming over
down.explanation: PIVOT(i.e. “turn”). Solution is TO then VIP (i.e. “somebody”, as in “to be a somebody”) which are then reversed (indicated by “coming over”), like so: PIV-OT.

down.text: Mechanism showing relative time?
down.explanation: GRANDFATHER CLOCK(i.e. “mechanism showing… time”). Solution riffs on a double meaning of “relative”, here being a grandfather.

down.text: Less easy going back with Queen
down.explanation: STERNER(i.e. “less easy”). Solution is STERN (the “back” of a ship) followed by ER (i.e. “Queen”, specifically Elizabeth Regina).

down.text: See what one’s forgotten about relative merit
down.explanation: RELEARN(i.e. “see what one’s forgotten about”). Solution is REL (a recognised abbreviation of “relative”) followed by EARN (i.e. “merit”).

down.text: Main set ignore dreadful feeling baby boomers are best?
down.explanation: GENERATIONISM(i.e. “feeling baby boomers are best”). “Dreadful” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of MAIN SET IGNORE.

down.text: Let others go without a freebie
down.explanation: GIVEAWAY(i.e. “freebie”). Solution is GIVE WAY (i.e. “let others go”) placed around or “without” A, like so: GIVE(A)WAY.

down.text: Sea wall peril – mad how courses of bricks are laid
down.explanation: PARALLELWISE(i.e. “how courses of bricks are laid”). “Mad” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SEA WALL PERIL.

down.text: Bone decay turned up in a part of the body
down.explanation: TORSO(i.e. “part of the body”). Solution is OS (Latin for “bone” – think of ossuaries such as the Catacombs of Paris) and ROT (i.e. “decay”) both reversed (indicated by “turned up”, this being a down clue) like so: TOR-SO.

down.text: How one may get a date with Charlie, perhaps, corrupt baron
down.explanation: RADIOCARBON(i.e. “how one may get a date”, as in carbon-dating something to determine its age). Solution is RADIO C (i.e. “Charlie, perhaps”, i.e. C in the phonetic alphabet) followed by an anagram (indicated by “corrupt”) of BARON, like so: RADIO-C-ARBON.

down.text: Audacity of revolutionary English movement out of India
down.explanation: CHEEKINESS(i.e. “audacity”). Solution is CHE Guevara (i.e. “revolutionary”) followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and KINESIS (i.e. “movement”) once the final I as been removed (indicated by “out of India”, “India” being I in the phonetic alphabet), like so: CHE-E-KINESS. Not a classic.

down.text: Revolutionary, a leading one on street
down.explanation: ANARCHIST(i.e. “revolutionary”). Solution is AN ARCH (i.e. “a leading”) followed by I (Roman numeral “one”) and ST (a recognised abbreviation of “street”).

down.text: Powerful politician setting FBI agent after good man Reagan?
down.explanation: STRONGMAN(i.e. “powerful politician”). Solution is G-MAN (i.e. “FBI agent”) being “set…after” ST (i.e. “good man”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “saint”) and RON (i.e. “Reagan”, specifically former US President Ronald Reagan), like so: ST-RON-GMAN.

down.text: Philosopher’s trick involving singular lines
down.explanation: BertrandRUSSELL(i.e. “philosopher”). Solution is RUSE (i.e. “trick”) including or “involving” S (a recognised abbreviation of “singular”) and followed LL (i.e. “lines”, L being a recognised abbreviation of “line”). A philosopher I’m faintly familiar with – a rarity for me!

down.text: Spy hero’s ways of conveying emotion
down.explanation: SMILEYS(i.e. “ways of conveying emotion”). Solution refers to George Smiley, “spy hero” of John le Carré’sTinker Tailor Solider Spy. A solution that’s rather wearing flares and a kipper tie in internet terms.

down.text: Not so much on empty estate for renter
down.explanation: LESSEE(i.e. “renter”). Solution is LESS (i.e. “not so much”) followed by EE (i.e. “empty estate”, i.e. the word “estate” will all its middle letters removed).

down.text: Odd soul music one can dance to
down.explanation: RUMBA(i.e. “music one can dance to”). Solution is RUM (i.e. “odd”) followed by BA (i.e. “soul” – in ancient Egyptian religion the ba is the soul, represented as a bird with a human head. Trippy.)

down.text: Land surrounded by water regularly dissolves
down.explanation: ISLE(i.e. “land surrounded by water”). “Regularly” indicates the solution is derived from taking every other letter fromDISSOLVES.
